results.title: Alice Moyle
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: on music”.
Alice Moyle was born in South Africa on 25th December 1908 and spent her first four years there before migrating out to Australia with her parents. She learned the piano and studied music at school, attending the University of Melbourne Conservatorium where she graduated with a Bachelor of Music in 1930. Alice Moyle’s first experience of Aboriginal music was listening to recordings made by Professor Elkin when she was attending courses at the Faculty of Music at Sydney University. These recordings were to prepare teachers for work in the outback. In 1959 Alice made the first of many field trips into the outback to continue the process of recording and archiving Aboriginal music. She has continually tried to inspire others with her experiences and knowledge in Aboriginal music and culture and is adamant that music be included as an essential component in the study of Aboriginal culture. This documentary is a recorded interview between Alice Moyle and James Murdoch.

results.title: Alexeieff's commercials
results.brief_description: A collection of advertising films made by French lithographer and animator, Alexander Alexeieff, some using his own ‘pinboard’ device, and others more conventional methods of animation. The reel includes: Fumees - which took a year to make on the pinboard and lasts barely a minute, with the smoke made from hundreds of fine oscillating lines superimposed densely on each frame, and Le seve de la terre - with delicately animated glass beads to represent drops of oil.

results.title: Alexander and the terrible, horrible, no good, very bad day (K)
results.brief_description: Anyone can have a bad day, but no one wants to have one quite as awful as seven year old Alexander’s. Whether it’s his mother forgetting to pack dessert in his lunch, or the dentist discovering he has a new cavity, nothing goes right for Alexander from sun-up to sun-down. Alexander will not only win children’s sympathy, he’ll remind the child in every adult how those little tragedies can accumulate to make an otherwise normal day seem like a catastrophe. Based on the best selling children’s book by Judith Viorst.

results.title: Alejandro Mamani: a case study in culture and personality
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Ira R. Abrams, Coast Community College District and Holt, Rinehart and Winston
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Faces of culture”.
Alejandro Mamani is a leader in his Bolivian mountain community, but he is an old man and believes himself possessed of evil spirits. Many remedies are tried to rid him of these spirits, from traditional forms of exorcism to sleeping tablets, but all attempts fail and after making his will he eventually commits suicide. Did he go mad or did he simply make use of his culture to leave life, once he saw there was no further use for him and his affairs were in order? Narrated by David Carradine.

results.title: Alcoholism
results.brief_description: The film portrays alcoholism as a mental health problem and as an illness that can respond to treatment. Demonstrates that the causes of this illness are imbedded personality difficulties often relating back to the early formative years of the victim’s childhood. The film discusses different forms of alcoholism and the different treatment required for each type. The role of Alcoholics Anonymous is covered and a plea made for increased public facilities for the treatment of alcoholics.

results.title: Alcohol is our problem (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Why do young people drink? This video examines some of the influences. Interviews with young people, parents, youth workers and a psychologist provide an insight into the issues and suggestions for overcoming the problem.

results.title: Alcohol is our problem
results.brief_description: This video examines the pressures - peer group, media, parents and adults - and reasons why some young people drink alcohol. Interviews with young people, parents, youth workers and psychologists provide an insight into these issues. Suggestions for overcoming the problems are put forward.

results.title: Alcohol and the human body
results.brief_description: Explains the source of alcohol in liquours produced by fermentation from wheat, grapes, corn and other plants. Diagrams show what happens to alcohol in the human body, how it deadens the judgement centres, affects the vision, slows up muscle responsivenss and may result in unconsciousness. The problem drunkard is diagnosed as a sick person requiring medical treatment. Alcohol is shown to be a social problem as well as a personal health issue.
